message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes suggests sarcoidosis. Non-caseating granulomas are a characteristic histology of sarcoidosis. Silica particles surrounded by collagen are seen in silicosis, golden-brown fusiform rods are seen in Coccidioidomycosis, and patchy interstitial lymphoid infiltrate into walls of alveolar units are seen in lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia.

We refer to our medical knowledge on the presentation of various diseases. The constellation of symptoms - painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes - suggest the patient has sarcoidosis. Non-caseating granulomas are the typical histological finding in sarcoidosis, whereas option (A) is seen in silicosis, (B) in Whipple disease, and (C) in lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest sarcoidosis, which is characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Option A describes findings in silicosis, option B describes findings in Whipple's disease, and option C describes findings in lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes are classic features of sarcoidosis. Transbronchial biopsy would typically show non-caseating granulomas. Option A describes findings in silicosis, option B describes findings in Whipple disease, and option C describes findings in lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes strongly indicates sarcoidosis, which is characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Option A is characteristic of silicosis, option B is characteristic of Whipple disease, and option C is characteristic of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes is characteristic of sarcoidosis. The biopsy would most likely show non-caseating granulomas, which are the hallmark histological finding in sarcoidosis. Silica particles are seen in patients with silicosis, golden-brown fusiform rods are seen in patients with Whipple disease, and patchy interstitial lymphoid infiltrate into walls of alveolar units is seen in patients with lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia.

The presentation of painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes suggests sarcoidosis, and the lung biopsy characteristic of sarcoidosis is non-caseating granulomas. Option A describes the pathology of silicosis, Option B describes the pathology of Actinomycosis, and Option C describes the pathology of non-specific interstitial pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a diagnosis of sarcoidosis, which is characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Silicosis is another possible diagnosis but is characterized by birefringent silica particles. The other options are not typically seen in sarcoidosis.

The symptoms of painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes suggest sarcoidosis, which is characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Option A and B are characteristic of occupational lung disease and Whipple disease, respectively. Option C is seen in interstitial lung disease.

The presentation of painful shin nodules, uveitis, and calcified hilar lymph nodes is consistent with sarcoidosis, which is characterized histologically by the presence of non-caseating granulomas. Option A describes the histology of silicosis, Option B describes the histology of Whipple's disease, and Option C describes the histology of lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia.
